briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. Welcome to the climate briefing for February 5, 2026. Based on the 126 climate-related news items collected today, we will provide an in-depth analysis of domestic and international climate change trends and response efforts.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Intensifying Climate Crisis: From Winter Olympics to Vulnerable Populations
sections.content: The climate crisis is profoundly impacting various aspects of our lives, posing significant challenges, particularly to the sustainability of the Winter Olympics. With rising hosting costs and increased reliance on artificial snow due to climate change, the International Olympic Committee (IOC) is even considering moving the 2026 Winter Olympics to January [1, 5, 113, 116, 119]. More concerning is the prediction that 3.8 billion people will be exposed to heatwaves if global temperatures rise by 2 degrees, coupled with reports that 22.5% of climate-vulnerable populations in Korea experienced social isolation for more than 7 days due to cold waves, demonstrating that climate change is no longer a distant future issue [2, 7, 118]. Experts warn that current economic models, which disregard extreme weather and climate tipping points, could lead to a global financial collapse, emphasizing that the climate crisis is an urgent reality, not a subject for debate [13, 107, 122].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Achieving Carbon Neutrality Goals: Strengthening Local Government Capacity is Urgent
sections.content: A red flag has been raised regarding South Korea's carbon neutrality goals. Out of 226 basic local governments nationwide, only 11 received an A grade in the evaluation of their Carbon Neutrality Master Plans, while a staggering 87 localities, approximately 40%, received a 'failing grade' of D [18, 24, 28, 46]. Specifically, Geoje City and 31 local governments in the Daegu-Gyeongbuk region received low evaluations, prompting calls for urgent and effective countermeasures [14, 27]. These results suggest that many local governments submitted similar, 'cookie-cutter' plans, leading to a lack of effectiveness, and indicate significant anticipated setbacks in achieving the 2030 carbon neutrality target [34]. While Haenam County in Jeollanam-do was the sole recipient of the top A grade, establishing itself as a leading model for rural and fishing communities [16, 17, 31, 35, 51], this strongly indicates the need for a comprehensive overhaul to strengthen the carbon neutrality capabilities of all local governments.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Domestic and International Renewable Energy Transition: The Importance of AI and Public-Private Cooperation
sections.content: The global transition to renewable energy is accelerating, with Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology and public-private cooperation emerging as key drivers. H-Energy suggested that the variability of renewable energy can be addressed by AI, emphasizing the importance of operational algorithms [57, 75, 86]. Gwangju Bank and LG Energy Solution signed a joint business agreement to target the renewable energy bidding market, signaling an expansion of financial support for Virtual Power Plants (VPPs) [56, 66, 71, 72, 74, 80, 81, 88, 89, 90, 93, 96, 97, 100, 101]. Domestically, Incheon's Jung-gu has established itself as a leading city for new and renewable energy for three consecutive years, promoting integrated support projects [55, 60, 61, 64, 67, 69, 70, 82, 87]. Haenam County has initiated the creation of a new and renewable energy public fund, demonstrating local-based energy transition efforts [58]. Internationally, Australia has surpassed 50% renewable energy penetration thanks to battery deployment, and oil-producing Saudi Arabia is investing 2 billion dollars in a solar power project in TÃ¼rkiye, confirming that the expansion of renewable energy is an irreversible global trend [65, 84].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Policy and Industry Efforts for Climate Change Response in Korea
sections.content: Domestically, various policy efforts and industrial advancements are actively underway to address climate change. Samcheok City in Gangwon Province is investing 480.2 billion won to establish a comprehensive natural disaster reduction plan, and Jeollanam-do is actively pursuing the establishment of a Marine and Fisheries Climate Change Response Center, demonstrating proactive responses at the local community level [3, 4, 9]. Seoul City is accelerating greenhouse gas reduction with its 'Climate-Friendly Building Project,' and Gimcheon City is undergoing organizational restructuring for efficient policy implementation, including the creation of a 'Climate and Energy Division' to integrate carbon neutrality, energy welfare, and urban forest projects [15, 21]. In the industrial sector, eco-friendly steel plates with 20% reduced carbon emissions are being mass-produced [53]. Furthermore, the life insurance industries of Korea and Japan have agreed to jointly address the challenges of a super-aged society and climate change, indicating a broadening awareness of climate change across various sectors [6]. The upcoming 2026 ESG Sustainable Management Awards, the Climate & Air Environment Industry Exhibition, and the Clean Air Climate Tech Global Conference further demonstrate the commitment to moving towards a carbon-neutral society through sustainable management and technological innovation [10, 11, 12].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Global Climate Crisis Awareness and Geopolitical Energy Competition
sections.content: On a global scale, the deepening awareness of the climate crisis is coinciding with a new phase in the competition for energy hegemony. Particularly, the surge in electricity demand driven by the development of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology is making a 'green transformation' centered on renewable energy inevitable [76]. In this context, an analysis suggests that the United States is falling behind China in the field of AI power supply, with the gap in renewable energy investment and discriminatory US policies cited as reasons [63, 68, 104]. Meanwhile, warnings continue that international economic models are failing to adequately capture the risks of climate change, potentially leading to a global financial crisis, thus raising the need for new economic models that go beyond GDP [107, 110, 122]. Amidst these circumstances, the EU is showing signs of re-evaluating its climate diplomacy after the COP30 Summit [125], and the Arctic Frontiers Conference addressed sovereignty, climate change, and research at the forefront, indicating that the international community faces complex climate issues [120].

briefing.closing: As we have reviewed in today's briefing, the climate crisis is intensifying globally, and immediate and effective responses are urgently needed. While various efforts are being made both domestically and internationally, strengthening the capacity of local governments to achieve carbon neutrality goals and adopting a strategic approach to energy transition in the AI era will become even more crucial. This concludes today's climate briefing.

articles.description: In 2025, solar power, electric vehicles, and other clean energy technologies contributed over one-third to China's economic growth and drove over 90% of investment growth. The output value of China's clean energy sector reached a record 15.4 trillion RMB (approximately 2.1 trillion USD) in 2025, accounting for about 11.4% of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP), a figure equivalent to the economic scale of Brazil or Canada. The latest analysis by Carbon Brief, based on official figures, industry data, and analyst reports, shows that the actual size of China's clean energy sector almost doubled between 2022 and 2025; if considered as an independent economy, its scale would rank eighth globally. Other key findings of this analysis include: These investments in clean energy manufacturing represent a significant bet on the energy transition in China and globally, also providing impetus for governments and businesses to maintain this momentum. However, long-term trends remain uncertain, especially in the solar sector. Affected by the new pricing mechanism under Document No. 136, the growth rate of solar power installed capacity has slowed, and the central government's related targets are significantly lower than the actual expansion levels of recent years. If the slowdown continues, these industries may shift from being drivers of economic growth to drag factors, while exacerbating the issue of â€œovercapacityâ€ in the industrial sector and further worsening international trade friction. But even if the central government sets cautious targets for clean energy over the next five years, the plans of local governments and state-owned enterprises...

The output value of China's clean energy sector reached a record 15.4 trillion RMB (approximately 2.1 trillion USD) in 2025, accounting for about 11.4% of its Gross Domestic Product (GDP), a figure equivalent to the economic scale of Brazil or Canada. Carbon Brief.
